analysis.raw_content:
Transcription/extraction from the provided page (page number shown: 21)

Title
- Contextual front setbacks

Primary rule (boxed)
- Contextual setbacks apply if, and only if, the average of the existing setbacks on the same side of the block is 30' or greater.

Process header
- How to determine if a contextual setback applies using Fig 15 below, as an example.

Decision/steps (flowchart text)
- Does block have more than 3 lots? (incl project lot)
- Note: If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' (max. 10 lots).
- Yes Exclude the following types of lots:
  • Flag lot (C)
  • Multi-family use w/ 3+ units (G)
  • Corner lot facing cross street (H)
- Is the number of remaining lots more or less than 5 or more?
- Yes Exclude the smallest and largest setbacks:
  • Smallest (D)
  • Largest (E)
  Find the average of the remaining lots (incl. subject lot). If greater than 30', it applies.

Numerical example (callout at right of flow)
- 30 (A)
- 33 (B)
- + 35 (F)
- 98 ÷ 3 = 32.7

Figure caption
- Fig 15 Example of a block with a contextual setback of 32.7'

Lots shown in Fig 15 (A–H) with legible labels/notes
- A: Single-Family. Setback label: 30'
- B: Single-Family. Setback label: 33'
- C: Flag lot (labeled “Flag lot”). Excluded in process.
- D: Single Family. Setback label: 29'. Excluded as “Smallest (D)”.
- E: Single Family. Setback label: 37'. Excluded as “Largest (E)”.
- F: Single-Family. Setback label: 35'
- G: Multiple Family (3+ units). Excluded in process. (A numerical setback label may be present but is not clearly legible in the image.)
- H: Corner lot facing other street. Excluded in process. Adjacent note: “Street sideyard”. (Any numeric dimension adjacent to this lot is not clearly legible in the image.)

Key (legend) labels visible
- lot line
- Sidewalk
- Buildable area
- Curb
- Required setbacks
- Existing house

Notes on legibility
- All text above is transcribed exactly where legible. Any measurements for lots G and H are not clearly readable in the provided image and are therefore not reported.
